No matter how well the mirrors are adjusted, there are always areas beside or behind the vehicle that the driver of a truck or car cannot see.
These areas are called blind spots.
Many accidents happen at intersections because a cyclist is in the truck’s blind spot.
A smart cyclist slows down and lets the truck turn first.

q:
It’s warm and you’re driving with the window open.
Does this affect fuel consumption?

A. Yes.
B. No.
e:
LESSON 30
Driving with the window open affects fuel consumption.
When the window is open, the vehicle’s air resistance increases.
At low speeds this effect is limited, but at higher speeds the added drag causes a noticeable rise in fuel consumption — up to 5–10% more at highway speed.

q:
You have to drive downhill for a long distance. What should you do?

A. Let the car roll downhill in neutral.
B. Shift to a lower gear.
C. Keep driving and brake regularly.
e:
LESSON 31
Even when driving downhill, you should engage a lower gear.
Rule of thumb: descend in the same gear you would use to climb the same hill.
This allows engine braking and prevents brake wear.

q:
What is the maximum permitted speed on a raised area within a built-up area in the Brussels-Capital Region?

A. 20 km/h.
B. 30 km/h.
C. 50 km/h.
e:
LESSON 12
Throughout the country, the maximum permitted speed on a raised area is 30 km/h, provided that it is properly signposted.

q:
Are you allowed to overtake a moped rider on the left on a raised area within a built-up area?

A. Yes, always.
B. Yes, if you leave one metre of lateral safety distance.
C. No.
e:
LESSON 16
On a raised area, you may only overtake a cyclist on the left.
(When the new traffic code comes into effect at the end of 2026, this will also be prohibited.)

q:
It is night. A driver is overtaking another car.
May the high beams be on during the overtaking?

A. Yes.
B. No.
e:
LESSON 11
High beams must not be used:
- when the road is continuously and sufficiently lit so that you can see 100 metres ahead;
- when they would dazzle an oncoming road user;
- when a vehicle is driving less than 50 metres ahead of you and you are not overtaking it immediately. If you are overtaking, you may use them.
- when approaching a rail vehicle or a boat.

q:
Which traffic sign can replace the blue mandatory sign to obtain the same result?

A. Sign 1.
B. Sign 2.
C. Sign 3.
e:
LESSON 24
1 = Danger sign: succession of dangerous bends.
2 = Prohibition sign: no right turn.
3 = Danger sign: traffic allowed in both directions after a section of the road with one-way traffic.

q:
Can it be dangerous to always use cruise control?

A. Yes.
B. No.
e:
LESSON 12
Cruise control is a feature found in most modern vehicles. It helps promote safer and more economical driving by reducing fuel consumption.
Once activated, it maintains a constant speed without the driver needing to press the accelerator.
However, it does not take poor road conditions into account.
In cases of snow, ice, or slippery surfaces, the car’s wheels can lose grip while cruise control continues to maintain the preset speed. This can cause loss of control or skidding, especially if the driver brakes suddenly to deactivate the system.
In such conditions, experts strongly recommend not using cruise control to maintain full control of the vehicle

q:
This boy is 1.45 metres tall.

A. He must sit in an adapted child seat.
B. He may sit in an adapted child seat.
C. He may no longer sit in an adapted child seat.
e:
LESSON 10
Children under 18 years old and smaller than 1.35 m must be transported in an approved child restraint system that meets the required standards.
A child taller than 1.35 m may still be transported in a special child seat.
Children under 18 may not be transported in the front seat in a rear-facing child seat, unless there is no front airbag or it can be deactivated.

q:
This girl is 12 years old and 1.45 metres tall.
She is sitting in the back seat of the car and is wearing a seat belt.
Is that correct?

A. Yes, because she is 1.45 metres tall.
B. No, she must sit in a child seat because she is only 12 years old.
e:
LESSON 10
Children under 18 years old and smaller than 1.35 m must be transported in an approved child restraint system that meets the required standards.
A child taller than 1.35 m may still be transported in a special child seat.
Children under 18 may not be transported in the front seat in a rear-facing child seat, unless there is no front airbag or it can be deactivated.

q:
When must the rear fog light be on?

A. Always when there is fog.
B. When visibility is less than 100 metres.
C. When visibility is less than 50 metres.
e:
LESSON 11
A car must have one or two red rear fog lights, which must be switched on:
in fog, when visibility is less than about 100 metres;
in snowfall, when visibility is less than about 100 metres;
in heavy rain, they must always be on in Belgium.

q:
If, in fog, visibility is about 110 metres...

A. the rear fog light must be on.
B. the rear fog light may be on.
C. the rear fog light may not be on.
e:
LESSON 11
A car must have one or two red rear fog lights which must be switched on:
in fog, when visibility is less than about 100 metres;
in snowfall, when visibility is less than about 100 metres;
in heavy rain, they must always be switched on in Belgium.

q:
What is the maximum speed allowed in Wallonia on an ordinary road when using studded tyres?

A. 60 km/h.
B. 70 km/h.
C. 90 km/h.
e:
LESSON 4
Studded tyres may be used from 1 November to 31 March on vehicles with a maximum authorised mass of up to 3.5 tonnes.
The maximum permitted speed is:
- on motorways and roads with 2×2 lanes separated by a central strip: 90 km/h;
- on ordinary roads in all regions: 60 km/h.

q:
What is the maximum speed allowed in the Flemish Region on an ordinary road when using studded tyres?

A. 60 km/h.
B. 70 km/h.
C. 90 km/h.
e:
LESSON 4
Studded tyres may be used from 1 November to 31 March on vehicles with a maximum authorised mass of up to 3.5 tonnes.
The maximum permitted speed is:
- on motorways and roads with 2×2 lanes separated by a central strip: 90 km/h;
- on ordinary roads in all regions: 60 km/h.

q:
It’s snowing. When must you switch on your dipped-beam headlights?

A. Always when it’s snowing.
B. As soon as visibility is less than 100 metres.
C. As soon as visibility is less than 200 metres.
e:
LESSON 11
During the day, you must switch on your dipped-beam headlights:
- in rain, when you cannot see farther than 200 metres;
- in fog, when you cannot see farther than 200 metres;
- in snowfall, when you cannot see farther than 200 metres;
- or in other situations (e.g. smoke from a fire) when visibility is less than 200 metres.

q:
It’s snowing, when must you switch on the rear fog light?

A. Always when it’s snowing.
B. As soon as visibility is less than 100 metres.
C. As soon as visibility is less than 200 metres.
e:
LESSON 11
When you are driving, you must switch on the rear fog light:
- in rain, when you cannot see farther than 100 metres;
- in fog, when you cannot see farther than 100 metres;
- in snowfall, when you cannot see farther than 100 metres;

q:
Which traffic sign is associated with the road marking called shark’s teeth?

A. With sign 1.
B. With sign 2.
C. With sign 3.
e:
An inverted triangle means you must give way to drivers on the road you are about to enter and stop if necessary.
If there are no drivers on the crossing road, you don’t have to stop and may enter the intersection.
A line formed by inverted triangles, also known as shark’s teeth, indicates the place where you must stop if necessary.
If it’s not really necessary, you don’t have to make a full stop.

q:
The maximum permitted speed in this built-up area is 30 km/h.
Must you give way if pedestrians cross the road?

A. Yes, because the speed limit is 30 km/h.
B. No, they only have priority on a pedestrian crossing.
e:
LESSON 7
A pedestrian who wants to cross the road at a place where there is no pedestrian crossing must give way themselves.
Nevertheless, drivers must always be cautious.

q:
In areas where the speed limit is 30 km/h, pedestrians always have priority when crossing the road.

A. True.
B. False.
e:
LESSON 7
A pedestrian who wants to cross the road at a place where there is no pedestrian crossing must give way themselves.
Nevertheless, drivers must always be cautious.

q:
A one-way street in a built-up area.
What is the grey car on the left side of the road allowed to do?

A. Stop only.
B. Stop and park.
C. Neither stop nor park.
e:
LESSON 25
On a one-way roadway, a car may be stopped or parked on either the right or the left side.

q:
A one-way street in a built-up area.
What is the car allowed to do at that place?

A. Stop.
B. Stop and park.
C. Neither stop nor park.
e:
LESSON 25
On a one-way roadway, a car may be stopped or parked on either the right or the left side, except of course when other signs or road markings prohibit it.

q:
This driver wants to turn left at this junction.
Even if there are no other road users, the driver must first come to a complete stop before entering the junction.

A. True.
B. False.
e:
LESSON 19
The give-way sign (inverted triangle) means that you must yield to other drivers and, if necessary, come to a complete stop.
If there are no other drivers, you don’t need to stop completely and may enter the junction.
If there is a STOP sign, however, you must come to a complete stop.

q:
This driver wants to turn right at this junction.
No other road users are visible.
Must he switch on the right indicator?

A. Yes, it’s always required.
B. No, if there’s no one around, it’s pointless.
e:
LESSON 21
Every lateral movement you make must be signalled using the indicator.
It doesn’t matter whether there are other drivers or not.

q:
This driver wants to turn right at this junction.
Even if there are no other road users, the driver must first come to a complete stop before entering the junction.

A. True.
B. False.
e:
LESSON 19
If there is a STOP sign you must come to a complete stop.
The give-way sign (inverted triangle) means that you must yield to other drivers and, if necessary, come to a complete stop.

q: Are you allowed to overtake a moped on the left with a car in a bicycle zone?
e:
In a bicycle zone, motor vehicles are not allowed to overtake a cyclist, scooter, or any other means of transport considered equivalent to a bicycle.
Other vehicles (for example, a moped) may be overtaken on the left in a bicycle zone, provided that the maximum permitted speed is not exceeded.

q: In this bicycle zone, is the car allowed to overtake a cyclist?
e:
LESSON 3
In a bicycle zone, motor vehicles are not allowed to overtake a cyclist, scooter, or any other means of transport considered equivalent to a bicycle.
Other vehicles (for example, a moped) may be overtaken on the left in a bicycle zone, provided that the maximum permitted speed is not exceeded.

q:
This cyclist is 16 years old. There is no cycle path.
May she ride there outside a built-up area?

A. Yes.
B. No.
e:
LESSON 3
If there is a cycle path, a cyclist must use it (unless it is not rideable).
It is forbidden to ride a bicycle on the pavement within a built-up area, except for children under 10, who may always ride on the pavement or on the raised verge.
Outside built-up areas, cyclists may, if there is no usable cycle path and provided they ride on the right-hand side of the road, ride on the pavement or on the raised verge.

q:
This girl is 8 years old. She is cycling on the roadway within a built-up area.
May she also ride on the raised pavement?

A. Yes.
B. No.
e:
LESSON 3
If there is a cycle path, a cyclist must use it (unless it is not rideable).
It is forbidden to cycle on the pavement within a built-up area, except for children under 10, who may always ride on the pavement or on the raised verge.
Outside built-up areas, cyclists may, if there is no usable cycle path and provided they ride on the right-hand side of the road, ride on the pavement or on the raised verge.

q:
This girl is 15 years old. She is cycling on the roadway within a built-up area.
May she also ride on the raised pavement?

A. Yes.
B. No.
e:
LESSON 3
If there is a cycle path, a cyclist must use it (unless it is not rideable).
It is forbidden to cycle on the pavement within a built-up area, except for children under 10, who may always ride on the pavement or on the raised verge.
Outside built-up areas, cyclists may, if there is no usable cycle path and provided they ride on the right-hand side of the road, ride on the pavement or on the raised verge.

q:
What ends 100 metres further?

A. A yellow zone.
B. The road becomes one-way.
C. A priority road.
e:
LESSON 19
The yellow priority sign with the supplementary sign indicates that the priority road ends 100 metres further. At the next junction, you will have to give way.

q:
May this car park at that place?

A. Yes, because the roadway is not divided into lanes.
B. No, because it is outside the built-up area.
e:
LESSON 26
You are not allowed to park outside built-up areas on the carriageway of a priority road.
Stopping, however, is allowed.

q:
What is the maximum speed allowed in the Walloon region on this road after passing the yellow sign?

A. 60 km/h.
B. 70 km/h.
C. 90 km/h.
e:
LESSON 12
It is a normal roadway divided into two lanes.
In the Walloon Region, the maximum permitted speed is 90 km/h.
In the Flemish and Brussels Regions, it is 70 km/h.
The yellow sign has nothing to do with speed — it is a priority-road sign indicating that you are driving on a priority road.

q:
This roadway is divided into two lanes.
What is the maximum speed allowed in the Brussels Region after passing the yellow sign?

A. 60 km/h.
B. 70 km/h.
C. 90 km/h.
e:
LESSON 12
It is a normal roadway divided into two lanes.
In the Walloon Region, the maximum permitted speed is 90 km/h.
In the Flemish and Brussels Regions, it is 70 km/h.
The yellow sign has nothing to do with speed — it is a priority-road sign indicating that you are driving on a priority road.

q:
At what maximum speed may this car drive past the yellow sign within a built-up area in the Brussels Region?

A. 30 km/h.
B. 50 km/h.
C. 70 km/h.
e:
LESSON 12
It is a roadway within a built-up area.
In the Walloon and Flemish Regions, the maximum permitted speed inside built-up areas is 50 km/h.
In the Brussels Region, it is 30 km/h.
The yellow sign has nothing to do with speed — it is a priority-road sign indicating that you are driving on a priority road.

q:
At what maximum speed may this car drive past the yellow sign within a built-up area in the Walloon Region?

A. 30 km/h.
B. 50 km/h.
C. 70 km/h.
e:
LESSON 12
It is a roadway within a built-up area.
In the Walloon and Flemish Regions, the maximum permitted speed inside built-up areas is 50 km/h.
In the Brussels Region, it is 30 km/h.
The yellow sign has nothing to do with speed — it is a priority-road sign indicating that you are driving on a priority road.

q:
At what maximum speed may this car drive past this sign in the Brussels-Capital Region?

A. 30 km/h
B. 50 km/h
C. 70 km/h
e:
LESSON 6
This traffic sign indicates the end of a built-up area.
The maximum permitted speed outside built-up areas is:
- in the Flemish Region and the Brussels-Capital Region: 70 km/h
- in the Walloon Region: 90 km/h

q:
At what maximum speed may this car drive, inside a built-up area in the Walloon Region, past this sign?

A. 30 km/h
B. 50 km/h
C. 70 km/h
e:
LESSON 6
This sign indicates, inside a built-up area, the end of a 30 km/h zone.
The car therefore continues within the built-up area.
The maximum permitted speed inside built-up areas is:
- in the Flemish Region and the Walloon Region: 50 km/h
- in the Brussels-Capital Region: 30 km/h

q:
At what maximum speed may this car drive, inside a built-up area in the Flemish Region, past this sign?

A. 30 km/h
B. 50 km/h
C. 70 km/h
e:
LESSON 6
This sign indicates, inside a built-up area, the end of a 30 km/h zone.
The car therefore continues within the built-up area.
The maximum permitted speed inside built-up areas is:
- in the Flemish Region and the Walloon Region: 50 km/h
- in the Brussels-Capital Region: 30 km/h

q:
Nighttime, outside a built-up area.
Before starting to overtake, the driver of the blue car briefly used the horn.
Was he allowed to do that?

A. No, because it is night.
B. Yes, because it is outside the built-up area.
e:
LESSON 11
When may you use the horn?
- During the day:
Inside and outside built-up areas: to warn others and prevent an accident.
Outside built-up areas: to warn a driver you intend to overtake.
- Between dusk and dawn:
Only in case of imminent danger.
In all other cases, you must flash your headlights alternately instead of using the horn.

q:
It is night, outside a built-up area.
While the blue car is overtaking, the distracted driver of the white car suddenly swerves to the left.
What may the driver of the blue car do?

A. He may only use the main beams because it is night.
B. He may use the horn to avoid an accident.
e:
LESSON 11
When may you use the horn?
During the day:
Inside and outside built-up areas: to warn others and prevent an accident.
Outside built-up areas: to warn a driver you intend to overtake.
Between dusk and dawn:
Only in case of imminent danger.
In all other cases, you must flash your headlights alternately instead of using the horn.

q:
It is dusk inside a built-up area.
Before the driver of the white car started overtaking, he briefly flashed the high beams.
Was he allowed to do that?

A. Yes.
B. No, because he is driving inside a built-up area.
e:
LESSON 11
When may you use the horn?
During the day:
Inside and outside built-up areas: to warn others and prevent an accident.
Outside built-up areas: to warn a driver you intend to overtake.
Between dusk and dawn:
Only in case of imminent danger.
In all other cases, instead of using the horn, you should flash the headlights (switch between high and low beams).

q: May the car overtake the truck on the left?
e:
LESSON 16
The red circular prohibition sign indicates that drivers are forbidden to:
- overtake a combination of vehicles, or
- overtake any vehicle with more than two wheels.
The no-overtaking rule applies:
- up to and including the next intersection, or
- it ends earlier if you see the end-of-prohibition sign.
A car driver may therefore overtake a two-wheeled motorcycle.
But the motorcyclist may not overtake a car, because a car has more than two wheels.

q: May the motorcycle overtake the truck on the left?
e:
LESSON 16
The red circular prohibition sign indicates that drivers are forbidden to:
- overtake a combination of vehicles, or
- overtake any vehicle with more than two wheels.
The no-overtaking rule applies:
- up to and including the next intersection, or
- it ends earlier if you see the end-of-prohibition sign.
A car driver may therefore overtake a two-wheeled motorcycle.
But the motorcyclist may not overtake a car, because a car has more than two wheels.

q: May the motorcycle overtake the motorcycle on the left?
e:
LESSON 16

The no-overtaking rule applies:

- it ends earlier if you see the end-of-prohibition sign.

But the motorcyclist may not overtake a car, because a car has more than two wheels.

q: May the car overtake the truck on the left?
e:
LESSON 16
This prohibition sign indicates that trucks or combinations with a maximum authorised mass exceeding 3500 kg may not overtake:
- a combination of vehicles, or
- any vehicle with more than two wheels.
The no-overtaking rule applies:
- up to and including the next intersection, or
- ends earlier if you see the “end of overtaking prohibition” sign.
A car driver may therefore overtake a truck on the left after this sign.
A bus may also overtake, since it is not a truck.

q: May the car overtake the truck on the left?
e:
LESSON 16
The red circular prohibition sign indicates that drivers are forbidden to:
- overtake a combination of vehicles, or
- overtake any vehicle with more than two wheels.
The blue sign indicates that the overtaking prohibition begins 200 metres further ahead.

May the car overtake the horse-drawn cart on the left?

A. Yes.

q:
How far may an indivisible load extend in front of the car without any signalling?

A. 1 metre.
B. 0.5 metre.
C. Not at all.
e:
LESSON 10
A load may never extend beyond the front of the vehicle.
Keep this in mind if you ever transport a ladder on the roof rack.
At the rear, it may extend up to 1 metre.

q:
How far may an indivisible load extend in front of the car, without any signalling?

A. 1 metre.
B. 0.5 metre.
C. Not at all.
e:
LESSON 10
A load may never extend beyond the front of the vehicle.
Keep this in mind if you ever transport a ladder on the roof rack.
At the rear, it may extend up to 1 metre.

q:
How far may this pipe extend beyond the rear of the vehicle?

A. Not at all.
B. 0.5 metre.
C. 1 metre.
e:
LESSON 10
A load may extend up to 1 metre beyond the rear of the vehicle.
If you must carry a load that is indivisible or cannot be shortened or folded, it may extend up to 3 metres beyond the rear, provided that a warning panel is attached at the end of the load.

q:
How far may this pipe extend beyond the rear of the vehicle?

A. Not at all.
B. 0.5 metre.
C. 1 metre.
e:
LESSON 10
A load may extend up to 1 metre beyond the rear of the vehicle.
If you must carry a load that is indivisible or cannot be shortened or folded, it may extend up to 3 metres beyond the rear, provided that a warning panel is attached at the end of the load.

q:
How far may an indivisible load extend beyond the rear of the vehicle if it is properly marked?

A. 3 metres.
B. 1.5 metres.
C. 1 metre.
e:
LESSON 10
A load may extend up to 1 metre beyond the rear of the vehicle.
If the load is indivisible and cannot be shortened or folded, it may extend up to 3 metres beyond the rear, provided that it is properly marked with the required warning panel.
This load is not properly marked.

q:
In a van, the front seat can accommodate the driver and two passengers. What must be the minimum width of that seat?

A. 125 cm.
B. 130 cm.
C. 135 cm.
e:
LESSON 10
The width must be sufficient for:
Driver: 55 cm.
Each passenger: 40 cm.
Total: 55 + 40 + 40 = 135 cm.

q:
The fuel of your car is LPG or petrol.
Are you allowed to drive past this sign?

A. Yes.
B. No.
C. Yes, provided you switch from LPG to petrol.
e:
LESSON 10
This sign has nothing to do with the fuel your car uses.
It concerns the load you are carrying.
Prohibition sign C24b: no entry for drivers of vehicles transporting flammable or explosive substances.

q:
This truck is carrying tons of washing powder.
May it drive past this sign?

A. Yes.
B. No.
e:
LESSON 10
Meaning of sign C24a:
No entry for drivers of vehicles carrying dangerous goods.
Washing powder is not a dangerous substance.

q:
This sign indicates that drivers of certain (…) are not allowed to drive their vehicle past this sign.

A. Contaminated goods.
B. Dangerous goods.
C. Inflammable or explosive goods.
e:
LESSON 10
Meaning of sign C24a:
No entry for drivers of vehicles carrying dangerous goods.

q:
Up to how many metres before a pedestrian crossing is it forbidden to park on the roadway?

A. 1 metre.
B. 5 metres.
C. 10 metres.
e:
LESSON 7
It is forbidden to park or stop on a pedestrian crossing, even to let someone get in or out.
It is also forbidden to park or to stop on the roadway within 5 metres before the crossing (parking on the verge is allowed if possible).
The same rule applies to crossings for cyclists and two-wheeled mopeds.
After the crossing, parking and stopping are allowed, unless prohibited by traffic signs.

q:
May the car stop at that place within a built-up area to let a passenger get in?

A. Yes.
B. No.
e:
LESSON 7
It is forbidden to park or stop on a pedestrian crossing, even to let someone get in or out.
It is also forbidden to park or to stop on the roadway within 5 metres before the crossing (parking on the verge is allowed if possible).
The same rule applies to crossings for cyclists and two-wheeled mopeds.
After the crossing, parking and stopping are allowed, unless prohibited by traffic signs.

q:
A car may not park on the roadway within 5 metres before a pedestrian or cyclist crossing.
But may a driver stop there to let someone get in?

A. Yes.
B. No.
e:
LESSON 7
It is forbidden to park or stop on a pedestrian crossing, even to let someone get in or out.
It is also forbidden to park or stop on the roadway within 5 metres before the crossing (parking on the verge is allowed if possible).
The same rule applies to crossings for cyclists and two-wheeled mopeds.
After the crossing, parking and stopping are allowed, unless prohibited by traffic signs.

q:

But may a driver stop there to let someone get in?

A. Yes.
B. No.
e:
LESSON 7
It is forbidden to park or stop on a pedestrian crossing, even to let someone get in or out.
It is also forbidden to park or stop on the roadway within 5 metres before the crossing (parking on the verge is allowed if possible).
The same rule applies to crossings for cyclists and two-wheeled mopeds.
After the crossing, parking and stopping are allowed, unless prohibited by traffic signs.

q:
A driver has parked his car very badly.
But is he allowed to park there?

A. Yes, because there is a broken yellow line.
B. No, because there is a broken yellow line.
e:
LESSON 26
You may not park (but you may stop) next to a broken yellow line painted along the edge of the roadway.

q:
Is this lorry allowed to park on the roadway?

A. Yes.
B. No.
e:
LESSON 27
If you see this sign, it means you must park on the verge.
Parking on the roadway is not permitted.

q:
May this lorry park in that place?

A. Yes.
B. No.
e:
The traffic sign with the symbol of a lorry indicates that it is a location where lorries are allowed to park.
A car may stop briefly there to let a passenger get in or out.

q:
Is this lorry parked correctly?

A. Yes, because the roadway is not divided into lanes.
B. No.
e:
LESSON 27
The blue sign indicates that vehicles must park partly on the roadway and partly on the verge.

q:
Is this car parked correctly?

A. Yes.
B. No.
e:
LESSON 27
The blue sign indicates that vehicles must park partly on the roadway and partly on the verge.

q:
When you see this road sign, it means that all motor vehicles, including lorries, may park beyond the sign.

A. True.
B. False.
e:
LESSON 27
The road sign with the symbol of a lorry indicates a parking place reserved only for lorries.
Other motor vehicles, such as cars, are not allowed to park there.
However, a car may stop there briefly to let a passenger get in or out.

q:
Dad is walking in the street with his son who is sitting on a pony.
Dad is …

A. A pedestrian.
B. A driver.
e:
LESSON 7
A rider or a person who leads a horse is not a pedestrian, but a driver under the traffic rules.

q:
This prohibition sign relates to the maximum (…) of a vehicle, load included.

A. Length.
B. Width.
C. Height.
e:
LESSON 10
Because some bridges or tunnels are lower, this sign may impose a different maximum height.
Truck and bus drivers have often learned the hard way that this sign is not placed without reason.

q:
You park your car at 15:06 in a street where you must use a parking disc.
At what time do you set the arrow?

A. At 15:00.
B. At 15:15.
C. At 15:30.
e:
LESSON 27
On the parking disc, you set the arrow to the mark that follows your arrival time. The mark after 15:06 is 15:30.
You may then park for two hours, counted from the time shown by the arrow, unless a traffic sign specifies a different duration.
After that, you must move your car — you may not simply change the time on the parking disc.

q:
You parked your car in a street and spent the night at your grandparents’ house.
The next morning you want to leave, but the street has become a school street.
Are you allowed to drive away?

A. Yes, but only at walking speed.
B. No.
e:
LESSON 6
To reduce traffic congestion at the start and end of the school day, a street near a school may be closed twice a day to motor vehicles. When this happens, the street becomes a school street. This is indicated by a C3 (no entry) traffic sign, together with an additional panel stating SCHOOL STREET.
Who may enter a school street?
– Pedestrians, cyclists, and speed pedelecs.
– Residents of the street or drivers who have a garage there (with a permit).
– Priority vehicles.
– Vehicles with a special permit.

q:
At what maximum permitted speed may the car continue on this road in Flanders after passing this sign?

A. 50 km/h.
B. 70 km/h.
C. 90 km/h.
e:
LESSON 6
The yellow sign is a town-name sign. It only indicates that you are entering the territory of a municipality; it does not mark the start of a built-up area.
In Flanders and Brussels region, the maximum permitted speed on an ordinary road is 70 km/h.
In Wallonia the speed limit is 90 km/h.

q:
An accident without injuries.
What should you do if one of the drivers refuses to sign the European accident report?

A. You sign it and inform the insurance company.
B. You call the police.
e:
LESSON 29
In an accident without injuries, you normally do not need to call the police, but the European accident report must be completed and signed by all drivers involved.
By signing, you confirm that you agree with the information written on the form.
Once everyone has signed, nothing can be changed.
If one of the drivers refuses to sign the report, you call the police.

q:
A cyclist has been hit at an intersection and is lying unconscious on the ground.
Are you allowed to clear the intersection and carefully carry the cyclist to the side of the road?

A. Yes, you must clear the intersection.
B. No, an injured person must remain where they are.
e:
LESSON 29
In an accident with injured persons, you leave the injured where they are and call the emergency services.
If there are injured persons, the police must also come to make the official report.

q:
After which traffic sign can you commit a 4th-degree offence?

A. Sign 1.
B. Sign 2.
C. Sign 3.
e:
4th-degree offence
Fourth-degree offences are the most serious traffic violations.
They directly endanger the safety of people and, in a collision, almost inevitably lead to physical injury.
Examples include:
• ignoring the orders of an authorised person,
• not respecting the signalling at a level crossing,
• stopping or parking a vehicle on a level crossing,
• encouraging excessive speed,
• organising or taking part in speed races on public roads,
• overtaking on the left on a hill or in a bend when prohibited,
• reversing or driving in the opposite direction on a motorway or an expressway.

q:
Driving onto a level crossing when the red flashing light is operating and the barrier is descending is an offence of the …

A. … second degree.
B. … third degree.
C. … fourth degree.
e:
LESSON 4 / Offences
Fourth-degree offences are the most serious traffic violations.
They directly endanger people’s safety and, in the event of a collision, almost inevitably cause physical injury.
Examples include:
- ignoring the orders of an authorised person,
- not respecting the signalling at a level crossing,
- stopping or parking on a level crossing,
- encouraging excessive speed,
- organising speed races on public roads,
- overtaking on the left on a hill or in a bend when this is prohibited,
- reversing or driving in the opposite direction on a motorway or expressway.

q:
You are driving at 47 km/h in a residential area in Wallonia. What are the consequences?

A. You receive a fine.
B. You receive an immediate temporary withdrawal of your driving licence.
C. You will have to appear before the court.
e:
LESSON 12
You risk an immediate withdrawal of your driving licence as soon as you drive more than 30 km/h too fast on motorways, expressways or ordinary roads.
However, in a built-up area, a 30 km/h zone, or a residential area (woonerf), you already risk an immediate withdrawal if you drive more than 20 km/h too fast.
You risk a disqualification from driving as soon as you exceed the speed limit by more than 40 km/h on motorways, expressways or ordinary roads.
In a built-up area, a 30 km/h zone or a residential area, you already receive a disqualification once you exceed the speed limit by more than 30 km/h.
This is not decided by the police but by the judge when your case is handled in court.

q:
When are you required to use your direction indicator?

A. When entering and leaving a roundabout.
B. Only when entering a roundabout.
C. Only when leaving a roundabout.
e:
LESSON 19
When entering a roundabout, you may use your indicator, but it is not mandatory.
When leaving a roundabout, you must use the right indicator to show that you are exiting.

q:
There is heavy rain and visibility is reduced to 130 metres. Must the rear fog lights be switched on?

A. Yes, always in heavy rain.
B. No, because visibility is more than 100 metres.
C. Rear fog lights are never compulsory.
e:
LESSON 11
The rear fog light must be switched on:
in fog, when visibility is less than about 100 metres;
in snowfall, when visibility is less than about 100 metres;
in heavy rain, it must always be on in Belgium, regardless of visibility.

q:
After a breath test, your result is 0.25 mg/l. What happens?

A. You may leave because this is below the limit.
B. You receive a 3-hour driving ban.
C. You receive a 6-hour driving ban.
e:
LESSON 28
In a breath analysis, you blow into a device that measures the alcohol concentration in the alveolar air you exhale. The exact result appears on the screen (e.g. 0.25 mg/l).
- Less than 0.22 mg/l: you may continue to drive.
- 0.22 to less than 0.35 mg/l: you must surrender your licence for 3 hours. This is an offence and you will receive a fine.
- 0.35 mg/l or more: you must surrender your licence for 6 hours. An immediate withdrawal is possible. After those 6 hours, a new breath test is required.

q:
From how many cyclists in a group are two road captains required?

A. From 15 participants.
B. From 26 participants.
C. From 51 participants.
e:
LESSON 3
Cyclists riding in a group of 51 to 150 participants must be accompanied by two road captains.
They are not required to use the cycle paths and may ride two abreast on the roadway, provided the group stays together.

q:
The police stop you in a built-up area in Flanders because you were driving at 75 km/h. What are the consequences?

A. You receive a fine.
B. You receive an immediate temporary withdrawal of your driving licence.
C. You will have to appear before the court.
e:
LESSON 12
You risk an immediate withdrawal of your licence as soon as you drive more than 30 km/h too fast on motorways, expressways or ordinary roads.
But in built-up areas, 30 km/h zones, or residential areas, you already risk this when you drive more than 20 km/h too fast.
You risk a driving disqualification as soon as you exceed the speed limit by more than 40 km/h on motorways, expressways or ordinary roads.
In built-up areas, 30 km/h zones, or residential areas, you already receive a disqualification once you exceed the limit by more than 30 km/h.
This is decided by the judge, not by the police.

q:
After which signs do you have priority?

A. Only after sign 1.
B. Only after signs 1 and 2.
C. After all three signs.
e:
LESSON 19
- Sign 1 – B21: Narrow passage.
You have priority over traffic coming from the opposite direction.
- Sign 2 – A39: Two-way traffic after a one-way section.
This sign does not grant priority.
- Sign 3 – B19: Narrow passage.
You must give priority to oncoming traffic — so you do not have priority.

q:
During a police check, you realise that you forgot your wallet with your driving licence at home. What are the consequences?

A. You are not allowed to continue driving.
B. You only receive a first-degree fine.
C. You must show your driving licence at a police station within 5 days.
e:
INFO – DRIVING LICENCE
Not carrying your driving licence with you is not considered a serious offence. You may receive a small administrative fine, but you are generally allowed to continue driving.
However, you must present your licence at a police station within 5 days.
If your licence is lost or stolen, you may not drive until you receive a new one. A loss or theft certificate is not sufficient to allow you to drive.

q:
You are approaching an intersection where a police officer is standing with one arm raised.
What do you do?

A. You slow down and wait for the order he will give.
B. You stop.
C. You slowly enter the intersection.
e:
LESSON 17
When a police officer raises one arm vertically at an intersection, all road users must stop.
Anyone already on the intersection must leave it as quickly as possible.

q:
Just as you enter an intersection, a police officer raises one arm vertically.
What do you do?

A. You slow down and wait for the order he will give.
B. You stop.
C. You continue driving and leave the intersection.
e:
LESSON 17
When a police officer raises one arm vertically at an intersection, all road users must stop.
Anyone already on the intersection must leave it as quickly as possible.

q:
You are approaching an intersection where an officer is standing with one arm extended horizontally.
What instruction is the officer giving?

A. You must turn left.
B. You may continue driving, but not turn left.
C. You must stop.
e:
LESSON 17
When an officer extends one or both arms horizontally, road users approaching the officer’s chest or back must stop.
Road users approaching the officer’s fingertips or side may continue onto the intersection to go straight, turn left, or turn right.
An officer with both arms extended horizontally gives exactly the same instruction as with only one arm extended horizontally.

q:
You are approaching an intersection where an officer is standing with one arm extended horizontally.
What instruction is the officer giving?

A. You must turn right.
B. You may continue driving, but not turn right.
C. You must stop.
e:
LESSON 17
When an officer extends one or both arms horizontally, road users approaching the officer’s chest or back must stop.
Road users approaching the officer’s fingertips or side may continue onto the intersection to go straight, turn left, or turn right.
An officer with both arms extended horizontally gives exactly the same instruction as with only one arm extended horizontally.

q:
This girl’s moped has run out of fuel.

A. She may walk on the sidewalk.
B. She must walk on the sidewalk.
C. She must walk on the roadway.
e:
LESSON 7
A person pushing a broken-down moped is considered a pedestrian and must walk on the sidewalk.
If there is no sidewalk, they may walk on the cycle path or on the roadway.

q:
Out of fuel.
A car driver gets out and pushes his car further.

A. He remains a driver.
B. He is considered a pedestrian.
e:
LESSON 8
A person who pushes a motorcycle or a car is a driver.

q:
Why are you required to zipper-merge?

A. For safety, to avoid accidents.
B. To keep traffic flowing smoothly.
C. To be courteous in traffic.
e:
LESSON 2
Zipper-merging is mandatory in very slow traffic or traffic jams when a lane ends.
You may only merge into the free lane right before the lane reduction.

q:
You are driving on a priority road and you approach an intersection where a traffic officer is standing with one arm raised.

What do you do?
A. Enter the intersection because you are on a priority road.
B. Stop.
e:
LESSON 17
When a traffic officer raises one arm vertically, all road users must stop.
Anyone already in the intersection must leave it as quickly as possible.

q:
You approach this intersection and a traffic officer raises one arm vertically.
What do you do?

A. You stop.
B. You may continue driving because you are approaching from the direction of his torso.
e:
LESSON 17
When a traffic officer raises one arm vertically, all road users must stop.
Anyone already in the intersection must leave it as quickly as possible.

q:
You are approaching an intersection where an officer is standing with one arm extended horizontally.
What instruction is the officer giving?

A. You must turn right.
B. You may continue driving, but not turn right.
C. You must stop.
e:
LESSON 17
When an officer extends one or both arms horizontally, road users approaching the officer’s chest or back must stop.
Road users approaching the officer’s fingertips or side may continue onto the intersection to go straight, turn left, or turn right.
An officer with both arms extended horizontally gives exactly the same instruction as with only one arm extended horizontally.

q:
From what alcohol level in the breath are you committing an offence?

A. From 0.22 mg/l.
B. From 0.25 mg/l.
C. From 0.35 mg/l.
e:
LESSON 28
- If you have less than 0.22 mg/l, you may continue driving.
- If the result is 0.22 mg/l or more, but below 0.35 mg/l, you must hand over your driving licence for 3 hours.
It is an offence and you will receive a fine.
- If you have 0.35 mg/l or more, you must hand over your driving licence for 6 hours.
An immediate withdrawal of your licence is also possible, and you will receive a fine.
After those 6 hours, a new breath test or breath analysis will follow.

q:
You are driving at 120 km/h on a motorway and it starts raining heavily.
What do you do?

A. Keep a safe distance of 60 metres.
B. Slow down and increase the distance.
e:
LESSON 13
The faster you drive, the more distance you must keep.
A simple formula helps you calculate it: speed divided by two.
At 120 km/h, the safe following distance is 60 metres.
At 100 km/h, it becomes 50 metres.
But in heavy rain, snow or fog, you must slow down and increase the following distance.

q:
Are you allowed to park a car on the carriageway of an expressway?

A. Yes, inside a built-up area.
B. Yes, outside a built-up area.
C. No.
e:
LESSON 25
Stopping (being stationary) and parking are forbidden on an expressway.

q:
The driver of a car overtakes a cyclist riding on the roadway on the left side.
How much lateral clearance must he keep here?

A. 1 metre.
B. 1.5 metres.
C. Sufficient distance.
e:
LESSON 15
This image clearly shows a situation outside a built-up area.
- On the roadway:
When overtaking a pedestrian walking on the roadway, or a cyclist or moped rider using the roadway, you must keep at least 1.5 metres of lateral clearance.
- On a cycle path:
If the cyclist or moped rider is on a cycle path, you must also keep this 1.5-metre distance. (This distance also applies when meeting a cyclist coming from the opposite direction.)
Inside built-up areas, the required lateral clearance is 1 metre.
